data.title: Plans to Move Flat River Missouri Bridge
data.text:
TOWN & BUSINESS INDEX PAGE

HOME PAGE

Local Residents Interested In Move To Re-locate Old Iron Structure

Between Taylortown and Crawley

Many local residents are interested in a move to have the old iron bridge, formerly in service on the highway through Flat River, and which is being replaced by a modern concrete structure, moved to a new location further down stream where it will connect the main street through Taylortown and Crawley Bottom.

No doubt hundreds of others, when they hear that such a movement is on foot, will join them in doing what they can to bring about such action. As it is, a petition has been circulated and signed by many residents living in the territory which will be immediately effected requesting the county court to take such action. They point out that a second bridge over Flat River in the lead belt district is really a necessity which has long been needed, and that present conditions, with a new bridge being erected and the old one torn down and ready to move, make such a project now both practical and economical.

As the Taylortown-Crawley Bottom crossing is about the only practical one aside from the one used by the Main Street crossing, and as a second crossing is really badly needed, undoubtedly the movement will meet with general approval throughout the lead belt. It would open up a way for traffic through the district which did not care to come through the heart of Flat River which would be widely and generally used. The removal of the Browne Dry Goods Company building, on the corner where the Taylortown street intersects with the present paved route of the highway, and the substitution of a filling station there, with a clear view of the highway in both directions resulting therefrom, adds greatly to the safety of such a movement.

Those circulating the petition have stated their intention of presenting the matter to the Lead Belt Chamber of Commerce at their meeting next Monday evening.

Published by THE LEAD BELT NEWS, Flat River, St. Francois County, Missouri, Fri. Sept. 14, 1928.
